# goshell Command Reference

<!-- This file is auto-generated by scripts/cmdtree/cmdtree.go -->
<!-- Run: go run scripts/cmdtree/cmdtree.go -out-docs docs/COMMANDS.md -->

## Core Commands

### ls - List directory contents
```bash
goshell ls [file...] [flags]
  -a, --all                do not ignore entries starting with .
  -A, --almost-all         do not list implied . and ..
  -F, --classify           append indicator (*/=>@|) to entries
  -d, --directory          list directories themselves, not their contents
  -H, --human-readable     with -l, print sizes in human readable format
  -i, --inode              print the index number of each file
  --json                   output in JSON format
  -l, --long               use a long listing format
  -U, --no-sort            do not sort; list entries in directory order
  -1, --one                list one file per line
  -R, --recursive          list subdirectories recursively
  -r, --reverse            reverse order while sorting
  -S, --size               sort by file size, largest first
  -t, --time               sort by modification time, newest first
```

### pwd - Print working directory
```bash
goshell pwd
```

### cat - Concatenate files and print on the standard output
```bash
goshell cat [file...] [flags]
  -e, --e                  equivalent to -vE
  -n, --number             number all output lines
  -b, --number-nonblank    number nonempty output lines, overrides -n
  -A, --show-all           equivalent to -vET
  -E, --show-ends          display $ at end of each line
  -v, --show-nonprinting   use ^ and M- notation, except for LFD and TAB
  -T, --show-tabs          display TAB characters as ^I
  -s, --squeeze-blank      suppress repeated empty output lines
  -t, --t                  equivalent to -vT
```

### date - Print the current date and time
```bash
goshell date [+FORMAT] [flags]
  --iso-8601               output date/time in ISO 8601 format
  -u, --utc                print Coordinated Universal Time (UTC)
```

### dirname - Strip last component from file name
```bash
goshell dirname [path...]
```

### basename - Strip directory and suffix from file names
```bash
goshell basename NAME [SUFFIX] [flags]
  -s, --suffix=STR         remove a trailing SUFFIX
```

### realpath - Print the resolved path
```bash
goshell realpath [path...]
```

---

## File Operations

### cp - Copy files and directories
```bash
goshell cp [source...] [destination]
```

### copy - Alias for cp
```bash
goshell copy
```

### mv - Move (rename) files
```bash
goshell mv [source...] [destination]
```

### move - Alias for mv
```bash
goshell move
```

### rm - Remove files or directories
```bash
goshell rm [file...] [flags]
  -f, --force              ignore nonexistent files and arguments, never p...
  -r, --recursive          remove directories and their contents recursively
```

### remove - Alias for rm
```bash
goshell remove
```

### mkdir - Create directories
```bash
goshell mkdir [directory...] [flags]
  -p, --parents            no error if existing, make parent directories a...
```

### rmdir - Remove empty directories
```bash
goshell rmdir [directory...]
```

### touch - Update the access and modification times of each FILE to the current time
```bash
goshell touch [file...]
```

### stat - Display file or file system status
```bash
goshell stat [file...] [flags]
  --json                   Output in JSON format
```

### ln - Make links between files
```bash
goshell ln [OPTION]... TARGET LINK_NAME [flags]
  -b, --backup             make a backup of each existing destination file
  -f, --force              remove existing destination files
  -n, --no-dereference     treat LINK_NAME as a normal file if it is a sym...
  -r, --relative           create symbolic links relative to link location
  -s, --symbolic           make symbolic links instead of hard links
  -v, --verbose            print name of each linked file
```

### readlink - Print resolved symbolic links or canonical file names
```bash
goshell readlink [OPTION]... FILE... [flags]
  -f, --canonicalize       canonicalize by following every symlink
  -e, --canonicalize-existing  canonicalize, all components must exist
  -m, --canonicalize-missing  canonicalize without requirements on existence
  -n, --no-newline         do not output the trailing delimiter
  -q, --quiet              suppress most error messages
  -s, --silent             suppress most error messages
  -v, --verbose            report error messages
  -z, --zero               end each output line with NUL, not newline
```

### chmod - Change file mode bits
```bash
goshell chmod [OPTION]... MODE[,MODE]... FILE... [flags]
  -c, --changes            like verbose but report only when a change is made
  -R, --recursive          change files and directories recursively
  --reference=STR          use RFILE's mode instead of MODE values
  -f, --silent             suppress most error messages
  -v, --verbose            output a diagnostic for every file processed
```

### chown - Change file owner and group
```bash
goshell chown [OPTION]... OWNER[:GROUP] FILE... [flags]
  -c, --changes            like verbose but report only when a change is made
  -h, --no-dereference     affect symbolic links instead of referenced file
  --preserve-root          fail to operate recursively on '/'
  -R, --recursive          operate on files and directories recursively
  --reference=STR          use RFILE's owner and group
  -f, --silent             suppress most error messages
  -v, --verbose            output a diagnostic for every file processed
```

---

## Text Processing

### grep - Print lines that match patterns
```bash
goshell grep [options] PATTERN [FILE...] [flags]
  -A, --after-context=N    print NUM lines of trailing context
  -B, --before-context=N   print NUM lines of leading context
  -C, --context=N          print NUM lines of output context
  -c, --count              only print a count of matching lines per FILE
  -E, --extended-regexp    interpret PATTERN as an extended regular expres...
  -l, --files-with-matches  only print FILE names containing matches
  -L, --files-without-match  only print FILE names not containing matches
  -F, --fixed-strings      interpret PATTERN as fixed strings
  -i, --ignore-case        ignore case distinctions in patterns and data
  -v, --invert-match       select non-matching lines
  -n, --line-number        prefix each line of output with line number
  -x, --line-regexp        match only whole lines
  -m, --max-count=N        stop after NUM matches
  --no-filename            suppress the file name prefix on output
  -o, --only-matching      show only nonempty parts of lines that match
  -q, --quiet              suppress all normal output
  -r, --recursive          search directories recursively
  -H, --with-filename      print file name with output lines
  -w, --word-regexp        match only whole words
```

### egrep - Print lines that match patterns (extended regexp)
```bash
goshell egrep [options] PATTERN [FILE...] [flags]
  -C, --context=N          print NUM lines of context
  -c, --count              only print a count of matching lines
  -l, --files-with-matches  only print FILE names with matches
  -i, --ignore-case        ignore case distinctions
  -v, --invert-match       select non-matching lines
  -n, --line-number        prefix each line with line number
  -o, --only-matching      show only matched parts
  -q, --quiet              suppress all normal output
```

### fgrep - Print lines that match patterns (fixed strings)
```bash
goshell fgrep [options] PATTERN [FILE...] [flags]
  -C, --context=N          print NUM lines of context
  -c, --count              only print a count of matching lines
  -l, --files-with-matches  only print FILE names with matches
  -i, --ignore-case        ignore case distinctions
  -v, --invert-match       select non-matching lines
  -n, --line-number        prefix each line with line number
  -o, --only-matching      show only matched parts
  -q, --quiet              suppress all normal output
```

### head - Output the first part of files
```bash
goshell head [option]... [file]... [flags]
  -c, --bytes=N            print the first NUM bytes of each file
  -n, --lines=N            print the first NUM lines instead of the first 10
  -q, --quiet              never print headers giving file names
  -v, --verbose            always print headers giving file names
```

### tail - Output the last part of files
```bash
goshell tail [option]... [file]... [flags]
  -c, --bytes=N            output the last NUM bytes
  -f, --follow             output appended data as the file grows
  -n, --lines=N            output the last NUM lines, instead of the last 10
  -q, --quiet              never output headers giving file names
  --sleep-interval=DURATION  with -f, sleep for approximately N seconds betw...
  -v, --verbose            always output headers giving file names
```

### sort - Sort lines of text files
```bash
goshell sort [option]... [file]... [flags]
  -c, --check              check for sorted input; do not sort
  -d, --dictionary-order   consider only blanks and alphanumeric characters
  -t, --field-separator=STR  use SEP instead of non-blank to blank transition
  -f, --ignore-case        fold lower case to upper case characters
  -b, --ignore-leading-blanks  ignore leading blanks
  -k, --key=STR            sort via a key
  -n, --numeric-sort       compare according to string numerical value
  -o, --output=STR         write result to FILE instead of standard output
  -r, --reverse            reverse the result of comparisons
  -s, --stable             stabilize sort by disabling last-resort comparison
  -u, --unique             with -c, check for strict ordering; without -c,...
```

### uniq - Report or omit repeated lines
```bash
goshell uniq [option]... [input [output]] [flags]
  -D, --all-repeated       print all duplicate lines
  -w, --check-chars=N      compare no more than N characters in lines
  -c, --count              prefix lines by the number of occurrences
  -i, --ignore-case        ignore differences in case when comparing
  -d, --repeated           only print duplicate lines, one for each group
  -s, --skip-chars=N       avoid comparing the first N characters
  -f, --skip-fields=N      avoid comparing the first N fields
  -u, --unique             only print unique lines
  -z, --zero-terminated    line delimiter is NUL, not newline
```

### wc - Print newline, word, and byte counts for each file
```bash
goshell wc [option]... [file]... [flags]
  -c, --bytes              print the byte counts
  -m, --chars              print the character counts
  -l, --lines              print the newline counts
  -L, --max-line-length    print the maximum display width
  -w, --words              print the word counts
```

### cut - Remove sections from each line of files
```bash
goshell cut [OPTION]... [FILE]... [flags]
  -b, --bytes=STR          select only these bytes
  -c, --characters=STR     select only these characters
  --complement             complement the set of selected bytes, character...
  -d, --delimiter=STR      use DELIM instead of TAB for field delimiter
  -f, --fields=STR         select only these fields
  -s, --only-delimited     do not print lines not containing delimiters
  --output-delimiter=STR   use STRING as the output delimiter
```

### tr - Translate or delete characters
```bash
goshell tr [OPTION]... SET1 [SET2] [flags]
  -c, --complement         use the complement of SET1
  -d, --delete             delete characters in SET1, do not translate
  -s, --squeeze-repeats    replace repeated characters with single occurrence
  -t, --truncate-set1      first truncate SET1 to length of SET2
```

### nl - Number lines of files
```bash
goshell nl [OPTION]... [FILE]... [flags]
  -b, --body-numbering=STR  use STYLE for numbering body lines
  -i, --line-increment=N   line number increment
  -n, --number-format=STR  insert line numbers according to FORMAT
  -s, --number-separator=STR  add STRING after line number
  -w, --number-width=N     use N columns for line numbers
  -v, --starting-line-number=N  first line number
```

### paste - Merge lines of files
```bash
goshell paste [OPTION]... [FILE]... [flags]
  -d, --delimiters=STR     reuse characters from LIST instead of TABs
  -s, --serial             paste one file at a time instead of in parallel
  -z, --zero-terminated    line delimiter is NUL, not newline
```

### tac - Concatenate and print files in reverse
```bash
goshell tac [OPTION]... [FILE]... [flags]
  -b, --before             attach the separator before instead of after
  -r, --regex              interpret the separator as a regular expression
  -s, --separator=STR      use STRING as the separator instead of newline
```

### column - Columnate lists
```bash
goshell column [OPTION]... [FILE]... [flags]
  -c, --columns=N          output width in characters
  -x, --fillrows           fill rows before columns
  -o, --output-separator=STR  output separator for table mode
  -R, --right              right-align columns
  -s, --separator=STR      delimiter characters for -t option
  -t, --table              determine column count based on input
```

### fold - Wrap each input line to fit in specified width
```bash
goshell fold [OPTION]... [FILE]... [flags]
  -b, --bytes              count bytes rather than columns
  -s, --spaces             break at spaces
  -w, --width=N            use WIDTH columns instead of 80
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell fold -w 40 file.txt     # wrap lines at 40 columns
goshell fold -s -w 72 README    # wrap at spaces, 72 columns
```

### join - Join lines of two files on a common field
```bash
goshell join [OPTION]... FILE1 FILE2 [flags]
  -1, --1=N                join on this FIELD of file 1
  -2, --2=N                join on this FIELD of file 2
  -a, --a=N                also print unpairable lines from file FILENUM (...
  -e, --e=STR              replace missing fields with EMPTY
  -i, --i                  ignore case when comparing fields
  -t, --t=STR              use CHAR as input and output field separator
  -v, --v=N                print only unpairable lines from file FILENUM (...
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell join file1.txt file2.txt           # join on first field
goshell join -1 2 -2 1 file1.txt file2.txt # join field 2 of file1 with field 1 of file2
goshell join -t ',' data1.csv data2.csv    # join CSV files
```

### sed - Stream editor for filtering and transforming text
```bash
goshell sed [OPTION]... {script} [FILE]... [flags]
  -e, --expression=LIST    add the script to the commands to be executed
  -i, --in-place           edit files in place
  --in-place-suffix=STR    backup suffix for in-place edit
  -n, --quiet              suppress automatic printing of pattern space
  -r, --r                  use extended regular expressions (alias)
  -E, --regexp-extended    use extended regular expressions
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell sed 's/old/new/' file.txt        # replace first occurrence
goshell sed 's/old/new/g' file.txt       # replace all occurrences
goshell sed -i.bak 's/foo/bar/g' file    # in-place edit with backup
goshell sed '/pattern/d' file.txt        # delete matching lines
goshell sed -n '/pattern/p' file.txt     # print only matching lines
```

### awk - Pattern scanning and processing language
```bash
goshell awk [OPTION]... 'program' [FILE]... [flags]
  -v, --assign=LIST        assign value to variable (var=value)
  -F, --field-separator=STR  use FS for the input field separator
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell awk '{print $1}' file.txt          # print first field
goshell awk -F: '{print $1}' /etc/passwd   # use : as separator
goshell awk '/pattern/{print}' file.txt    # print matching lines
goshell awk 'BEGIN{print "start"} {print} END{print "end"}' file
goshell awk '{print $1, $NF}' file.txt     # print first and last field
```

---

## System Information

### env - Print environment variables
```bash
goshell env [NAME...] [flags]
  -i, --ignore-environment  start with an empty environment
  -0, --null               end each output line with NUL, not newline
  -u, --unset=STR          remove variable from the environment
```

### whoami - Print effective username
```bash
goshell whoami
```

### id - Print user and group information
```bash
goshell id [OPTION]... [USER] [flags]
  -g, --group              print only the effective group ID
  -G, --groups             print all group IDs
  -n, --name               print a name instead of a number
  -r, --real               print the real ID instead of the effective ID
  -u, --user               print only the effective user ID
```

### uname - Print system information
```bash
goshell uname [flags]
  -a, --all                print all information
  -i, --hardware-platform  print the hardware platform
  -s, --kernel-name        print the kernel name
  -r, --kernel-release     print the kernel release
  -v, --kernel-version     print the kernel version
  -m, --machine            print the machine hardware name
  -n, --nodename           print the network node hostname
  -o, --operating-system   print the operating system
  -p, --processor          print the processor type
```

### uptime - Tell how long the system has been running
```bash
goshell uptime [OPTION]... [flags]
  -p, --pretty             show uptime in pretty format
  -s, --since              system up since
```

### free - Display amount of free and used memory in the system
```bash
goshell free [OPTION]... [flags]
  -b, --bytes              show output in bytes
  -g, --gibibytes          show output in gibibytes
  -H, --human              show human-readable output
  -k, --kibibytes          show output in kibibytes
  -m, --mebibytes          show output in mebibytes
  -t, --total              show total for RAM + swap
  -w, --wide               wide output
```

### df - Report file system disk space usage
```bash
goshell df [OPTION]... [FILE]... [flags]
  -B, --block-size=N       scale sizes by SIZE before printing them
  -x, --exclude-type=STR   exclude file systems of type TYPE
  -H, --human-readable     print sizes in human readable format
  -i, --inodes             list inode information instead of block usage
  -l, --local              limit listing to local file systems
  -P, --portability        use the POSIX output format
  --total                  produce a grand total
  -t, --type=STR           limit listing to file systems of type TYPE
```

### du - Estimate file space usage
```bash
goshell du [OPTION]... [FILE]... [flags]
  -a, --all                write counts for all files, not just directories
  --apparent-size          print apparent sizes, rather than disk usage
  -B, --block-size=N       scale sizes by SIZE before printing them
  -b, --bytes              equivalent to --apparent-size --block-size=1
  -H, --human-readable     print sizes in human readable format
  -d, --max-depth=N        print total for directory only if N or fewer le...
  -0, --null               end each output line with NUL, not newline
  -x, --one-file-system    skip directories on different file systems
  -s, --summarize          display only a total for each argument
  -c, --total              produce a grand total
```

### ps - Report a snapshot of current processes
```bash
goshell ps [OPTION]... [flags]
  -a, --all                show processes for all users
  -f, --full               full-format listing
  -l, --long               long format
  --no-headers             don't print header line
  -p, --pid=N              show process with specified PID
  --sort=STR               sort by column (pid, cpu, mem, time)
  -u, --user=STR           show processes for specified user
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell ps                 # show current user's processes
goshell ps -a              # show all processes
goshell ps -f              # full format listing
goshell ps -p 1234         # show specific process
goshell ps --sort cpu      # sort by CPU usage
```

### kill - Send a signal to a process
```bash
goshell kill [OPTION]... PID... [flags]
  -l, --list               list signal names
  -s, --signal=STR         specify the signal to be sent
  -v, --verbose            report successful signals
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell kill 1234           # send SIGTERM to process 1234
goshell kill -9 1234        # send SIGKILL to process 1234
goshell kill -s HUP 1234    # send SIGHUP to process 1234
goshell kill -l             # list all signal names
```

### time - Time a simple command or give resource usage
```bash
goshell time
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell time sleep 2    # Time a sleep operation
goshell time            # Just show current time info
```

---

## Flow Control

### xargs - Build and execute command lines from standard input
```bash
goshell xargs [OPTION]... [COMMAND [INITIAL-ARGS]] [flags]
  -I, --I=STR              replace occurrences of REPLACE-STR
  -d, --delimiter=STR      input items are separated by DELIM
  -n, --max-args=N         use at most MAX arguments per command line
  -P, --max-procs=N        run at most MAX processes at a time
  -r, --no-run-if-empty    if there are no arguments, do not run
  -0, --null               input items are separated by a null character
  -t, --verbose            print commands before executing them
```

### watch - Execute a program periodically, showing output fullscreen
```bash
goshell watch [OPTION]... COMMAND [flags]
  -b, --beep               beep if command has a non-zero exit
  -c, --color              interpret ANSI color sequences
  -d, --differences        highlight differences between updates
  -e, --errexit            exit if command has a non-zero exit
  -n, --interval=FLOAT64   seconds to wait between updates
  -t, --no-title           turn off header
  -p, --precise            attempt run command in precise intervals
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell watch -n 1 file myfile.txt    # Watch a file for changes
goshell watch -n 5 dir ./logs         # Watch a directory
```

### yes - Output a string repeatedly until killed
```bash
goshell yes [STRING]...
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell yes              # outputs 'y' forever
goshell yes hello        # outputs 'hello' forever
goshell yes | head -5    # outputs 5 'y' lines
```

### nohup - Run a command immune to hangups
```bash
goshell nohup COMMAND [ARG]...
```

---

## Archive & Compression

### tar - Create, extract, or list archive files
```bash
goshell tar [OPTION]... [FILE]... [flags]
  -c, --create             create a new archive
  -C, --directory=STR      change to directory DIR
  -x, --extract            extract files from an archive
  -f, --file=STR           use archive file ARCHIVE
  -z, --gzip               filter through gzip
  -t, --list               list the contents of an archive
  --strip-components=N     strip N leading path components
  -v, --verbose            verbosely list files processed
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell tar -cvf archive.tar dir/        # create tar archive
goshell tar -czvf archive.tar.gz dir/    # create gzipped tar
goshell tar -xvf archive.tar             # extract tar archive
goshell tar -xzvf archive.tar.gz         # extract gzipped tar
goshell tar -tvf archive.tar             # list contents
goshell tar -xvf archive.tar -C /dest    # extract to directory
```

### zip - Package and compress files into a zip archive
```bash
goshell zip [OPTION]... ZIPFILE FILE... [flags]
  -C, --directory=STR      change to directory before adding
  -r, --recursive          recurse into directories
  -v, --verbose            verbose output
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell zip archive.zip file1.txt file2.txt   # create zip
goshell zip archive.zip dir/                   # zip directory
goshell zip -v archive.zip file.txt           # verbose output
```

### unzip - Extract files from a zip archive
```bash
goshell unzip [OPTION]... ZIPFILE [flags]
  -d, --directory=STR      extract files into directory
  -l, --list               list contents without extracting
  --strip-components=N     strip N leading path components
  -v, --verbose            verbose output
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell unzip archive.zip              # extract to current directory
goshell unzip -d /dest archive.zip     # extract to specific directory
goshell unzip -l archive.zip           # list contents
goshell unzip -v archive.zip           # verbose extraction
```

---

## Hash & Encoding

### hash - Compute and check file hashes
```bash
goshell hash [OPTION]... [FILE]... [flags]
  -a, --algorithm=STR      hash algorithm (md5, sha1, sha256, sha512)
  -b, --binary             read in binary mode
  -c, --check              read checksums from FILE and check them
  --quiet                  don't print OK for verified files
  -r, --recursive          hash files recursively
  --status                 don't output anything, use status code
  -w, --warn               warn about improperly formatted lines
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell hash file.txt                    # SHA256 hash
goshell hash -a md5 file.txt             # MD5 hash
goshell hash -r ./dir                    # hash all files in directory
goshell hash -c checksums.txt            # verify checksums
goshell hash file1 file2 > checksums.txt # create checksum file
```

### sha256sum - Compute and check SHA256 message digest
```bash
goshell sha256sum [OPTION]... [FILE]... [flags]
  -b, --binary             read in binary mode
  -c, --check              read checksums from FILE and check them
  --quiet                  don't print OK for verified files
  --status                 don't output anything, use status code
  -w, --warn               warn about improperly formatted lines
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell sha256sum file.txt           # compute hash
goshell sha256sum -c checksums.txt   # verify checksums
```

### sha512sum - Compute and check SHA512 message digest
```bash
goshell sha512sum [OPTION]... [FILE]... [flags]
  -b, --binary             read in binary mode
  -c, --check              read checksums from FILE and check them
  --quiet                  don't print OK for verified files
  --status                 don't output anything, use status code
  -w, --warn               warn about improperly formatted lines
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell sha512sum file.txt           # compute hash
goshell sha512sum -c checksums.txt   # verify checksums
```

### md5sum - Compute and check MD5 message digest
```bash
goshell md5sum [OPTION]... [FILE]... [flags]
  -b, --binary             read in binary mode
  -c, --check              read checksums from FILE and check them
  --quiet                  don't print OK for verified files
  --status                 don't output anything, use status code
  -w, --warn               warn about improperly formatted lines
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell md5sum file.txt           # compute hash
goshell md5sum -c checksums.txt   # verify checksums
```

### base64 - Base64 encode or decode data
```bash
goshell base64 [OPTION]... [FILE] [flags]
  -d, --decode             decode data
  -i, --ignore-garbage     ignore non-alphabet characters when decoding
  -w, --wrap=N             wrap encoded lines after N characters (0 = no w...
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell base64 file.bin                 # encode file
goshell base64 -d encoded.txt           # decode file
```

### base32 - Base32 encode or decode data
```bash
goshell base32 [OPTION]... [FILE] [flags]
  -d, --decode             decode data
  -w, --wrap=N             wrap encoded lines after N characters (0 = no w...
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell base32 file.bin                 # encode file
```

### base58 - Base58 encode or decode data (Bitcoin alphabet)
```bash
goshell base58 [OPTION]... [FILE] [flags]
  -d, --decode             decode data
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell base58 -d encoded.txt           # decode
```

---

## Data Processing

### jq - Command-line JSON processor
```bash
goshell jq [OPTION]... FILTER [FILE]... [flags]
  -c, --compact-output     compact output
  -n, --null-input         don't read any input
  -r, --raw-output         output raw strings
  -s, --slurp              read all inputs into array
  -S, --sort-keys          sort object keys
  --tab                    use tabs for indentation
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell jq -r '.name' data.json
```

### yq - Command-line YAML processor
```bash
goshell yq [OPTION]... FILTER [FILE]... [flags]
  -c, --compact-output     compact output
  -I, --indent=N           indentation level
  -n, --null-input         don't read any input
  -o, --output-format=STR  output format (yaml or json)
  -r, --raw-output         output raw strings
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell yq '.name' config.yaml
goshell yq -o json '.' config.yaml    # convert YAML to JSON
goshell yq '.items[]' data.yaml
```

### dotenv - Load environment variables from .env files
```bash
goshell dotenv [OPTION]... [FILE]... [flags]
  -x, --expand             expand variables in values
  -e, --export             output as export statements
  -q, --quiet              suppress warnings
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell dotenv                    # display vars from .env
goshell dotenv .env.local         # display vars from specific file
goshell dotenv -e                 # output as export statements
goshell dotenv -x                 # expand ${VAR} references
```

---

## Security & Random

### encrypt - Encrypt data using AES-256-GCM
```bash
goshell encrypt [OPTION]... [FILE] [flags]
  -a, --armor              ASCII armor (base64) output
  -b, --base64             base64 output (same as -a)
  -i, --iterations=N       PBKDF2 iterations
  -k, --key-file=STR       use key file for encryption
  -o, --output=STR         write output to file
  -p, --password=STR       password for encryption
  -P, --password-file=STR  read password from file
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell encrypt -p mypassword -o secret.enc file.txt
goshell encrypt -P ~/.password -a file.txt
```

### decrypt - Decrypt data using AES-256-GCM
```bash
goshell decrypt [OPTION]... [FILE] [flags]
  -a, --armor              input is ASCII armored (base64)
  -b, --base64             input is base64 (same as -a)
  -i, --iterations=N       PBKDF2 iterations
  -k, --key-file=STR       use key file for decryption
  -o, --output=STR         write output to file
  -p, --password=STR       password for decryption
  -P, --password-file=STR  read password from file
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell decrypt -p mypassword secret.enc
goshell decrypt -p mypassword -a < secret.b64
goshell decrypt -P ~/.password -o file.txt secret.enc
```

### uuid - Generate random UUIDs
```bash
goshell uuid [OPTION]... [flags]
  -n, --count=N            generate N UUIDs
  -x, --no-dashes          output without dashes
  -u, --upper              output in uppercase
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell uuid                  # generate one UUID
goshell uuid -n 5             # generate 5 UUIDs
goshell uuid -u               # uppercase output
goshell uuid -x               # no dashes (32 hex chars)
```

### random - Generate random values
```bash
goshell random [OPTION]... [flags]
  -c, --charset=STR        custom character set
  -n, --count=N            number of values to generate
  -l, --length=N           length of random strings
  --max=N                  maximum value for integers
  --min=N                  minimum value for integers
  -s, --separator=STR      separator between values
  -t, --type=STR           type: int, float, string, alpha, hex, password,...
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell random                         # random 16-char string
goshell random -t int --max 100        # random int 0-99
goshell random -t hex -l 32            # random 32-char hex
goshell random -t password -l 20       # random password
goshell random -n 5 -t int --max 10    # 5 random ints 0-9
goshell random -t custom -c "abc123"   # from custom charset
```

---

## TUI Pagers

### less - View file contents with scrolling
```bash
goshell less [OPTION]... [FILE] [flags]
  -N, --LINE-NUMBERS       show line numbers
  -S, --chop-long-lines    truncate long lines
  -i, --ignore-case        case-insensitive search
  -X, --no-init            don't clear screen on start
  -F, --quit-if-one-screen  quit if content fits on one screen
  -R, --raw-control-chars  show raw control characters
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell less file.txt
goshell less -N file.txt     # with line numbers
goshell less -S file.txt     # chop long lines
```

### more - View file contents page by page
```bash
goshell more [OPTION]... [FILE] [flags]
  -n, --line-numbers       show line numbers
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell more file.txt
goshell more -n file.txt     # with line numbers
```

---

## Comparison

### diff - Compare files line by line
```bash
goshell diff [OPTION]... FILE1 FILE2 [flags]
  -q, --brief              report only when files differ
  --color                  colorize the output
  -B, --ignore-blank-lines  ignore changes where lines are all blank
  -i, --ignore-case        ignore case differences
  -b, --ignore-space-change  ignore changes in amount of white space
  --json                   compare as JSON files
  -r, --recursive          recursively compare subdirectories
  -y, --side-by-side       output in two columns
  --suppress-common-lines  do not output common lines in side-by-side
  -u, --unified=N          output NUM lines of unified context
  -W, --width=N            output at most NUM columns
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell diff file1.txt file2.txt
goshell diff -u 5 old.txt new.txt         # 5 lines of context
goshell diff -y file1.txt file2.txt       # side-by-side
goshell diff -q dir1/ dir2/               # brief comparison
goshell diff --json config1.json config2.json
goshell diff -r dir1/ dir2/               # recursive
```

---

## Tooling

### lint - Check Taskfiles for portability issues
```bash
goshell lint [OPTION]... [FILE|DIR]... [flags]
  --fix                    auto-fix issues where possible
  -f, --format=STR         output format (text, json)
  -q, --quiet              only show errors, not warnings
  --strict                 enable strict mode (more warnings become errors)
```

**Examples:**
```bash
goshell lint                            # lint Taskfile.yml in current dir
goshell lint Taskfile.yml               # lint specific file
goshell lint ./tasks/                   # lint all Taskfiles in directory
goshell lint --strict Taskfile.yml      # enable strict mode
goshell lint -q Taskfile.yml            # only show errors
```

### cmdtree - Display command tree visualization
```bash
goshell cmdtree
```

### version - Print version information
```bash
goshell version [flags]
  -j, --json               Output version info as JSON
```

---

## Other Commands

### gops - A brief description of your command
```bash
goshell gops
```

### pipeline - A brief description of your command
```bash
goshell pipeline
```

### top - A brief description of your command
```bash
goshell top
```

+-- egrep                                    # Print lines that match patterns (exte...

+-- free                                     # Display amount of free and used memor...

+-- version                                  # Print version information
